refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Signal Prototypes

refsect2.title: struct GnomeDialog

warning.para: GnomeDialog is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Client code can pack widgets (for example, text or images) into vbox.

listitem.simpara: The middle portion of the dialog box.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_new ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_new is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Creates a new GnomeDialog, with the given title, and any button names in the arg list. Buttons can be simple names, such as _("My Button"), or gnome-stock defines such as GNOME_STOCK_BUTTON_OK, etc. The last argument should be NULL to terminate the list.

Buttons passed to this function are numbered from left to right, starting with 0. So the first button in the arglist is button 0, then button 1, etc. These numbers are used throughout the GnomeDialog API.

listitem.simpara: The title of the dialog; appears in window titlebar.
NULL-terminated varargs list of button names or GNOME_STOCK_BUTTON_* defines.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_newv ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_newv is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: See gnome_dialog_new(), this function is identical but does not use varargs.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_set_parent ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_set_parent is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Dialogs have "parents," usually the main application window which spawned them. This function will let the window manager know about the parent-child relationship. Usually this means the dialog must stay on top of the parent, and will be minimized when the parent is. Gnome also allows users to request dialog placement above the parent window (vs. at the mouse position, or at a default window manger location).

listitem.simpara: GnomeDialog to set the parent of.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_button_connect ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gnome_dialog_button_connect (GnomeDialog *dialog, gint button, GCallback callback, gpointer data);

warning.para: gnome_dialog_button_connect is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Simply g_signal_connect() to the "clicked" signal of the specified button.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_button_connect_object ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gnome_dialog_button_connect_object (GnomeDialog *dialog, gint button, GCallback callback, GtkObject *obj);

warning.para: gnome_dialog_button_connect_object is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: g_signal_connect_swapped() to the "clicked" signal of the given button.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_run ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_run is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Blocks until the user clicks a button, or closes the dialog with the window manager's close decoration (or by pressing Escape).

You need to set up the dialog to do the right thing when a button is clicked or delete_event is received; you must consider both of those possibilities so that you know the status of the dialog when gnome_dialog_run() returns. A common mistake is to forget about Escape and the window manager close decoration; by default, these call gnome_dialog_close(), which by default destroys the dialog. If your button clicks do not destroy the dialog, you don't know whether the dialog is destroyed when gnome_dialog_run() returns. This is bad.
So you should either close the dialog on button clicks as well, or change the gnome_dialog_close() behavior to hide instead of destroy. You can do this with gnome_dialog_close_hides().

listitem.simpara: If a button was pressed, the button number is returned. If not, -1 is returned.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_run_and_close ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_run_and_close is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: See gnome_dialog_run(). The only difference is that this function calls gnome_dialog_close() before returning, if the dialog was not already closed.

listitem.simpara: If a button was pressed, the button number. Otherwise -1.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_set_default ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_set_default is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: The default button will be activated if the user just presses return. Usually you should make the least-destructive button the default. Otherwise, the most commonly-used button.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_grab_focus ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_grab_focus is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: The button button will grab the focus. Use this for dialogs Where only buttons are displayed and you want to change the default button.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_set_sensitive ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_set_sensitive is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Calls gtk_widget_set_sensitive() on the specified button number.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_set_accelerator ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gnome_dialog_set_accelerator (GnomeDialog *dialog, gint button, const guchar accelerator_key, guint8 accelerator_mods);

warning.para: gnome_dialog_set_accelerator is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Set an accelerator key for a button.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_close ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_close is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: See also gnome_dialog_close_hides(). This function emits the "close" signal, which either hides or destroys the dialog (destroy by default). If you connect to the "close" signal, and your callback returns TRUE, the hide or destroy will be blocked. You can do this to avoid closing the dialog if the user gives invalid input, for example.

Using gnome_dialog_close() in place of gtk_widget_hide() or gtk_widget_destroy() allows you to easily catch all sources of dialog closure, including delete_event and button clicks, and handle them in a central location.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_close_hides ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_close_hides is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Some dialogs are expensive to create, so you want to keep them around and just gtk_widget_show() them when they are opened, and gtk_widget_hide() them when they're closed. Other dialogs are expensive to keep around, so you want to gtk_widget_destroy() them when they're closed. It's a judgment call you will need to make for each dialog.

listitem.simpara: If TRUE, gnome_dialog_close() calls gtk_widget_hide() instead of gtk_widget_destroy().

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_set_close ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_set_close is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: This is a convenience function so you don't have to connect callbacks to each button just to close the dialog. By default, GnomeDialog has this parameter set the FALSE and it will not close on any click. (This was a design error.) However, almost all the GnomeDialog subclasses, such as GnomeMessageBox and GnomePropertyBox, have this parameter set to TRUE by default.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if clicking any button should call gnome_dialog_close().

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_editable_enters ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_editable_enters is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Normally if there's an editable widget (such as GtkEntry) in your dialog, pressing Enter will activate the editable rather than the default dialog button. However, in most cases, the user expects to type something in and then press enter to close the dialog. This function enables that behavior.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_append_buttons ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_append_buttons is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: This function is mostly for internal library use. You should use gnome_dialog_new() instead. See that function for a description of the button arguments.

listitem.simpara: varargs list of additional buttons, NULL-terminated.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_append_button ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_append_button is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Add a button to a dialog after its initial construction. This function is mostly for internal library use. You should use gnome_dialog_new() instead. See that function for a description of the button argument.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_append_buttonsv ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_append_buttonsv is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: For internal use, language bindings, etc. Use gnome_dialog_new() instead.

listitem.simpara: NULL-terminated vector of buttons to append.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_append_button_with_pixmap ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gnome_dialog_append_button_with_pixmap (GnomeDialog *dialog, const gchar *button_name, const gchar *pixmap_name);

warning.para: gnome_dialog_append_button_with_pixmap is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Add a pixmap button to a dialog. gnome_dialog_new() does not permit custom buttons with pixmaps, so if you want one of those you need to use this function.

listitem.simpara: GnomeDialog to add the button to.
Name of the button, or stock button define.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_append_buttons_with_pixmaps ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gnome_dialog_append_buttons_with_pixmaps (GnomeDialog *dialog, const gchar **names, const gchar **pixmaps);

warning.para: gnome_dialog_append_buttons_with_pixmaps is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: Simply calls gnome_dialog_append_button_with_pixmap() repeatedly.

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_construct ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_construct is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: See gnome_dialog_new().

refsect2.title: gnome_dialog_constructv ()

warning.para: gnome_dialog_constructv is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: See gnome_dialog_new().

refsect2.title: GNOME_STOCK_BUTTON_OK

warning.para: GNOME_STOCK_BUTTON_OK is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: This button has been replaced by one in GTK+ and new code should use that.

refsect2.title: The "clicked" signal

listitem.simpara: the object which received the signal.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.
the object which received the signal.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.
